awd_abstract_narration:
The goal of the ComputerScienceForGeorgia (CS4GA) workshop will apply research and a variety of intervention experiences to a specific community in order to make computer science (CS) education available and accessible to all students within that community context.  While there is industry and parental support for CS in K12, the process of adding a new discipline has both systemic and community context specific nuisances. In order to effectively add a new discipline to an already packed school day without marginalizing large groups of students and whole communities, it is important to not only address the systemic processes and stimulate awareness among the various stakeholder groups but also to understand the barriers endemic to particular context, including but not limited to the location and population density of a community.  This project builds  on a current INCLUDES pilot initiative and can offer insights to a diversity of community stakeholders.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

inst.inst_street_address: 205 JESSE HILL JR DR SE STE 1652

por.por_cntn:
The 2019 Computer Science Summit/Workshop, CompSciCon, was organized as a multi-faceted event, addressing a wide rang of audiences, with a singular intention, to broaden participation in Computer Science (CS) education in Georgia. CompSciCon had two tracks, an implementation workshop for Local Education Agency (LEA) teams, facilitating the development of CS implementation plans for K-12 CS, and a workshop for students. The LEA workshop utilized the CSforAll SCRIPT tool which has been modified in Georgia to fit local context and address specific challenges uncovered during a previous NSF funded grant project (titled ?A4I?) which looked at CS implantation in rural, urban, and suburban contexts.

Intellectual Merit

CompSciCon was organized to be supportive of a state implementation grant which was a result of a recent legislative action that requires all high schools and middle schools in Georgia to offer CS by 2025. The legislation provides the incentive, the grant offers fiscal support, and CompSciCon was designed to complement these with guidance on how to implement CS, with an eye towards equity in CS education. Despite a legislative mandate, the why and how of implementation are often lost on educators. The summit provided context for implementing CS education, including a lunch talk from a Diversity and Equity Officer at Google, Dr. Kamau Bobb. Coupling training with legislation and funding is a compelling intersection of policy.

CompSciCon was held in Columbus Georgia and invitations to participate were sent to the surrounding rural LEAs. Half of the eight participating LEAs served predominantly African American communities and all but one are rural. These recruitment efforts were reflective of lessons learned during the A4I project. Efforts that do not specifically target underrepresented communities often don?t reach those communities. Many resources in Georgia are directed towards the Atlanta Metro area, leaving the rural communities to less supported in this regard. CompSciCon and future like-endeavors will target rural Georgia to stimulate CS education in rural, low-socio-economic, and high minority LEAs.

Broader Impact

Georgia has 16 Regional Education Agencies (RESAs) which represent and support geographical subgroups of the 183 LEAs. CompSciCon was geographically restricted but by inviting representatives from the various RESAs, we hoped to stimulate support for future workshops across the state. Since CompSciCon, two other RESAs representing predominantly rural LEAs have conducted similar workshops adding ten more LEAs to the list of those that have received training.

CompSciCon was sponsored by the CS4GA collective impact effort in Georgia and members of the collective participated in the experience. These members helped take the theoretical discussion of building local community partnerships, a component of the SCRIPT tool, into real world connections. Participating LEAs were able to network with PD and curriculum providers as well as local university and industry partners. Providing this networking component helps to actualize the steps needed to implement CS in the near term with fidelity. Partnering with CS4GA curriculum providers to host workshops for local students also afforded a visual context of what CS education looks like in the classroom. Partners unable to provide workshops were eager to do so at future events.

Outcomes

CompSciCon engaged eight LEA teams ranging in size from 3 to 20 members. Five of these LEAs had recently been awarded the state CS4GA Capacity grant to train Computer Science teachers and one was awarded the following year (the other two did not apply for the grant the following year and thus are still eligible). These LEA teams have now developed an implementation plan and received funding to support one of the most salient challenges to that Implementation. Since CompSciCon, three more workshops have been conducted, two with RESAs that were engaged during CompSciCon and one with a high minority populated suburb of Atlanta that heard about the event, received the grant, and wanted help developing a plan of implementation.

In the 2018-2019 school year, prior to CompSciCon, 2,300 students were enrolled in CS courses in the participating LEAs. In the 2019-2020, despite a global pandemic, 3,400 students were enrolled in CS courses, with an increase of 60 more students taking the AP CS A course. A true impact will be visible in the 2020 and 2021 school years and the CS4GA Data Team is tracking this cohort data to assess impact.

Due to the success of CompSciCon, CS4GA has partnered with the Constellations Center for Equity in Computing at Georgia Tech to formalize this workshop and offer it three times a year for the next four years. The next Georgia CS Summit, to be held in March of 2021, will be a two-day event with the first day focused on advocacy for equity in computing education and the second day another implementation workshop with specific recruitment in southeast Georgia, a rural region of Georgia which state data shows has low CS course offerings and enrollment.


Last Modified: 12/29/2020
Modified by: Bryan Cox
